name: N-Phenylbenzene-1,4-diamine
Reason: The basic molecular structure consists of two benzene rings connected through an amine (-NH) linker. A single benzene ring has a melting point of approximately 5.5 °C. Each amine group introduces an increase due to the capability of hydrogen bonding, which could be estimated around +20 °C for each. The two nitrogen atoms connected to the central benzene ring also create a symmetric arrangement that may result in more efficient packing, hence a slight increase in the melting point as well. However, the presence of two benzene rings also increases the molecular weight and the Van der Waals forces, which could contribute to increasing the melting point by approximately +30 °C for the whole molecule when compared to a single benzene unit.
Prediction: 5.5 (basic benzene unit) + 20 (effect of one amine group) + 20 (effect of the second amine group) + 30 (additional benzene ring and symmetrical arrangement) = 75.5
